displayed_text: Patient: The Xgeva, we stopped. Doctor: Enzalutamide, you’re still taking four pills a day? Patient: Yep. Doctor: The only drug that you’ve got on here -- Patient: for two weeks and two weeks off. Doctor: You got your hormone shot - the lisinopril five milligrams a day? Patient: Yep. Doctor: And a multi-vitamin? Patient: Once a day. Doctor: Any other medicine that you’d add to this or take off this list? (pause) Patient: Nope. (pause) Doctor: And you don’t get your treat – your hormone shot here, right?

Patient: Is it? Doctor: I may need to give you medicine to help control it. Like Imodium and things like that. Patient: Yeah, well then, okay. ‘Cuz, yeah, I’m taking the stool softener a day thinking that, that, that, you know? And then it be like watery. Doctor: Mmm, hmm. Patient: Yeah. It be like, it be like water. Doctor: Okay. Yeah, I think I’m going to give you medication. That way, when you’re out and about and all that, you can take that, and that won’t make you go so fast. Patient: Man. Man, that was so bad, so bad. Doctor: So, Patient: I did it twice on myself, man. ‘Cuz I went out, and I had to catch the bus back home. Man, it’s like I had to walk home ‘cuz I didn’t want to get on the bus. Doctor: Yeah. Patient: They’ll be saying, “What’s that smell like shit.” Doctor: Hmm.

Patient: Um hmm. Doctor: But after, the first year, every three months and then after that two to five years every six months, and then after that if everything stays okay then once a year. Patient: Because I take this serious. Doctor: Okay I can see that. Patient: I take this very, very, very serious. Doctor: The whole thing and I’m glad. Patient: You know I’m not trying to underestimate anything you know and you know because I never felt you know from the beginning I never felt… Doctor: Felt any symptoms. Patient: Yes. You know. Doctor: I understand. Neither did I. So we’ll get you to see Dr. R____ as soon as possible and I’ll see you back in three months. Patient: Okay. Doctor: And you get your blood test before you come back.

Patient: Okay. Doctor: And again, that’s the radiologists can’t agree on what it is. Patient: So, would I have to have something done to go into the adrenal glands or, uh, the, the tests that confirm that whether it is cancer or not cancer? Doctor: Um, no. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Um. And then if you decided to go with chemotherapy, it would be just one of the many spots that we would watch for change in response to. Patient: Right. So, I mean, as I said, I prefer to, to, to keep that to the last option, chemotherapy. Just because of, uh, how draining it is. Doctor: Right. Patient: B_, and my presumption is, if I stay with what I’m doing, that the PSA will continue to rise. As long as it continues to rise, it seems, um, with all the drugs I’ve had, it keeps going up. Doctor: Correct. So, when we did all the research with Enzalutamide, uh, patients on those studies stayed on treatment until either one of two things happened. Patient: Um Hmm. Doctor: They felt worse and the, because of the cancer or the scan showed new disease.

Family Member: Because that will be at least his third hormone shot. Doctor: Yeah. Family Member: And at some point, everybody’s saying those will stop working or could stop working. Doctor: They could stop working. Um. They will stop working eventually. Family Member: Mm, hmm. Doctor: I mean, usually, it takes a year or two. But, they will stop eventually. Family Member: Okay. Doctor: Sometimes longer than that. Family Member: Okay. Patient: At which point we’ll be transitioning to a different kind of treatment, hopefully. Doctor: Right. Family Member: Yes. Doctor: And, that’s the next discussion, what that is. And, that, that’s evolving, particularly for guys with your story.

Patient: Mm. Doctor: Alright, and then starting treatment when you just when you develop metastatic disease. Option two is what we call intermittent hormone therapy. So, what this approach means is that you would get hormone therapy, which is the primary treatment for prostate cancer. If you were here in this metastatic bucket, you can get started with hormone therapy. But you would get started on hormone therapy for six months and then we stop and then and that'll bring down your PSA and then we wait until some threshold PSA, your PSA is about 31 now, so we could wait until it gets to 31 again. And sometimes we wait until it’s 10 sometimes 50, but you know, we would, we would only give you the hormone therapy intermittently, so not continuously so you get it for six months, two shots, shot us for three months, lasts for three months. Family Member: Mhm. Doctor: So you get it for two shots and then you stop. What this medicine does is it makes your testosterone levels go to zero. So it works on your testicles which produce the testosterone and it makes them stop producing testosterone. So people have like menopause type symptoms. Mm? Family Member: So you’re going to use Lupron? Doctor: Yes, exactly. Family Member: Mhm. Doctor: So we use Lupron Family Member: Shots? Doctor: Mhm. So people get hot flashes. People get low libido, can have erectile dysfunction. And sometimes your testicles will actually get smaller. People can feel more fatigued you sometimes get some weight gain. There can be some cardiovascular like, um like changes in your cholesterol. Let me remind myself though, what other medicines are you on now? Family Member: Cinepro for high blood pressure. Cinepro 1800. Um.. Doctor: Is it potassium? Patient: Potassium.

Family Member: Mm, hmn. Doctor: But that would be potentially something you could participate in. Right now I would be a little bit worried about putting you on it with these gasping things that I can’t explain- Family Member: Mm, hmm. Doctor: because it might affect our ability to get the therapy in. Uhm, we have another study which I, uh - Transformer - we have a first-in-human study of a drug that comes from plum seeds. In laboratory studies it looks like it can attack and kill prostate cancer cells. So this is a study where we’re looking at a drug that now is in I.V. form to see how often does it affect the PSA, how often do you get side effects that we can’t give it to you. So it’s more about the side effects and whether it helps you or not. Family Member: Mm, hmm. Doctor: Some of the data says that it could help you, but we don’t know. We’ve never given it to enough men. We treat a number of men and if they do okay, then we go to a higher dose. Family Member: Mm, hmm. Doctor: You know that’s an early phase—Phase I study. That clearly has no data as to whether it works. And so you could window it in at this point, but if the scans when we get them show that the stuff that’s in your liver is even big in other areas, Family Member: Mm, hmm. Doctor: you know whether or not you have the willingness or sort of the time to sort of participate in something that’s you know experimental of that nature of a brand new drug is questionable. But some people clearly want to avoid chemotherapy at all costs and are willing to try that even if you know it doesn’t work and they were to miss that opportunity for chemotherapy. So everybody sort of chooses based on who they talk to, who their neighbors are, who’s been through chemo. Doctor: What they are willing to think about. Patient: Yes, I have the time. Yeah.

Patient: Run down. Yeah, it did, it was making me really tired. Doctor: Yeah. Patient: But I mean, I was surviving--I was able to get by with work and stuff, it was-- Family Member: You got really--you were really, really tired. Doctor: I may just adjust you today because if we can keep that eye and, you know, everything else from getting worse-- Patient: Yeah, the drops have been wonderful. Doctor: --because the nerves affecting things is a big problem. If that happens, then that's tougher to reverse. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Okay. So let's go one notch slightly lower in terms of your dose. Patient: Okay. Yeah, I missed it yesterday, I was going to come in all dressed up as a doctor, and-- Doctor: Yep. Healthcare Professional: So we just need to do a date clarification 'cause- so the pharmacy can use the last order the last time. Just have to change today’s date, so.

Patient: Right. That’s why – Doctor: Yeah. Patient: I gave you that excel spreadsheet. Doctor: Yes. Patient: So there’s no question… Doctor: Not – not a Patient: …this is what J____ takes every single day. Doctor: Yes so then we know. Patient: And I’m very religious about it. Doctor: The other part now is sort of what do we do? Patient: Yes. Doctor: So let’s say we gather this information, we’re biopsying terrific, uh you know it’s all good for lab stuff, but what are we doing to actually treat it? There are several options. One, pills. Patient: Mhmm.

Patient: Okay. Doctor: Because I need to check, if that, that we were to move you to, let’s say your AR-V7 was positive - Patient: Right. Doctor: They may want you to stay on the Enzalutamide. Patient: Right, right. Doctor: Or we could stop the TGF-A drug. Patient: Right. Doctor: And, then, you could move into that study. Patient: Okay. Doctor: If you are AR-V7 negative and, uh, phase one study is of more interest to you, we can say, “Okay, you’re gonna stop as of this date the, the current study.” Patient: Right-- the drugs Doctor: And then we could reserve the slot for the new trial.

Family Member: He can’t get it at K_____ C____? Doctor: Not if it’s a trial. If it’s a trial. Family Member: If it’s not a trial he could get it at K____ C_____? Doctor: Yeah. Yeah, well you'd have to get the doctor up there to give it like I can't prescribe it and you do it there. But we can have you go see. Family Member: Are you sure? Patient: Dr. F_____. Doctor: Dr. F_____ is a radiation doc- Family Member: Oh. Doctor: -so you’ll need a med onc doc like me. Family Member: Ohh, I forgot about that. so doctor connect or somebody up that way. Doctor: See someone up that way. Family Member: Is there even someone up that way even? I mean, I don't know.

Thank you for your valuable contributions to our study! Our goal is to understand how doctors can communicate better with patients by looking at different perceptions of the doctors’ qualities. Understanding your personal experiences with the medical system will help us to contextualize your responses. We invite you to share insights by answering the following questions. Your answers to these questions are strictly confidential and anonymous.

About how long has it been since you las.Within the past year (anytime less than: About how long has it been since you last saw a doctor or other health professional about your health?:::Within the past year (anytime less than 12 months ago)

During the past 12 months, not counting.3 times: During the past 12 months, not counting times you went to an emergency room, how many times did you go to a doctor, nurse, or other health professional to get care for yourself?:::3 times

Sometimes doctors care more about what i.disagree: Sometimes doctors care more about what is convenient for them than about their patients' medical needs.:::disagree

Doctors are extremely thorough and caref.agree: Doctors are extremely thorough and careful.:::agree

You completely trust doctors' decisions.neutral: You completely trust doctors' decisions about which medical treatments are best.:::neutral

A doctor would never mislead you about a.disagree: A doctor would never mislead you about anything.:::disagree

All in all, you trust doctors completely.neutral: All in all, you trust doctors completely.:::neutral

People of my ethnic group receive the sa.disagree: People of my ethnic group receive the same medical care from doctors and healthcare workers as people from other groups:::disagree

People of my ethnic group are treated th.neutral: People of my ethnic group are treated the same as people of other groups by doctors and healthcare workers:::neutral

Doctors have the best interests of peopl.neutral: Doctors have the best interests of people of my ethnic group in mind:::neutral

Which of the following best describe you.Employed: Which of the following best describe your current occupational status? Mark all that apply.:::Employed

What is the highest grade or level of s.12 years or completed high school: What is the highest grade or level of schooling you completed?:::12 years or completed high school

Are you of Hispanic or Latino origin or.No, not Hispanic or Latino: Are you of Hispanic or Latino origin or descent?:::No, not Hispanic or Latino

What race or races do you consider yours.Black or African American: What race or races do you consider yourself to be?:::Black or African American

displayed_text:
Family Member: Any other tests that we need to know about? Blood work and bone biopsy? Doctor: That’s all what I can think of right now. Healthcare Professional: and recent scans. Doctor: Yeah the scans are pretty recent so we should be able to use those. Family Member: With this – so with this new regime would he get the CAT scan bone scan and stuff sooner than six months?
DOC Probably oh yeah, yes. Definitely sooner than six months. It’s between eight to twelve weeks. And that’s all in this protocol we’re gonna read? And is that still N__ or R__ or no more N__ or R__ … Doctor: Well they will be from here so she will bring you the copy of the consent. Today you’re just taking the copy to read. But uh no then it will be S__ is the downtown person. I think you may have met her. Family Member: We met S___, yeah. Patient: Okay. Family Member: And we stay in S__’s study? Doctor: Yeah. Family Member: The patient… Doctor: You can yeah. As long as until you say no or I say no. (Laughs) Family Member: No I mean we’re happy to help so.

Patient: Yeah. Doctor: They put it in there. Patient: You can see the real thing if you’d like. It’s right there. (Laughs) Doctor: And, how are you doin’ with just the bowels, to start with? Still everything okay? Patient: Uh. With my bowels? Doctor: Yes. Patient: Actually, better. Doctor: Better? Okay. Patient: Since the radiation. Doctor: Okay. So, once a day, twice a day? How often do you --- Patient: Well, somedays a couple of times a day. Doctor: Okay. Patient: Maybe three times.

Patient: Um hum. Doctor: In order to keep you on this study, uh, from the side effect perspective, we’re going to need to temporarily stop the medication again, unfortunately- Because of this hemoglobin being eight point nine. Okay? Patient: Um hum. Doctor: Uh, it’s very likely that when you come back on September fifth, your hemoglobin will be above nine, hopefully, above ten, it will recover some, in other words, uh, and then given that the hemoglobin has improved, we can put you back on the medication, but it will be at the two-hundred milligram dose. It’ll be a second level of dose reduction. Okay? Patient: Hum. Doctor: I don’t think you’ll need to go lower than that. Okay? But I think the two-fifty in terms of the anemia, uh, it did cause the same problem, again, to a lesser degree, but it did still cause the same problem. Uh, so my preference, if you want to remain on the study, which I think is reasonable, would be as of today to ask you to stop the medication until you come back and see us on September the fifth. And on that day, what we’re probably going to recommend, provided that your hemoglobin has increased again, preferably above ten, but at least above nine, is we’re going to put you back on the second dose level reduction which will be two hundred milligrams per day. Patient: Hum. Okay. Family Member: So between now and September fifth, a week-? Doctor: That’s, that’s two weeks. Yeah. Family Member: Does he go in for another blood transfusion or are you expecting the hemoglobin to increase pretty much on its own as he regulates without the medication? Doctor: One idea would be to check a hemoglobin level at a local laboratory, uh, one week from now just to see where we are at. And if it has made significant progress on its own, we can skip the blood transfusion. And if it looks like it’s only gone up like one-tenth of a point, then we can perhaps schedule a blood transfusion before September fifth. So if you agree to that, I can give you, uh, a prescription for a complete blood count. Patient: Okay.

Patient: Not a problem; it hasn’t really changed much. Doctor: Come on in. Okay. Hold on one second. Patient: That’s alright. Doctor: And what side effects are you having from the drugs? Patient: Um, I mean other than tiredness at, at the end of the day. (pause) Doctor: Any other bumps or lumps? Patient: No, no. Doctor: Ooo, it’s a little gooey under there, it is. Patient: What’s that? Doctor: A little gooey under there! Patient: Yeah. Patient: Well, that’s that the uh, ointment.
